Thanks for the pointer to the problem page. This particular example of
inscrutable web design features a line containing about 1MB of
backslashes inside a <SCRIPT> tag. This was proving to be troublesome
for a zero-or-more production in one of our regexes devoted to finding
likely URIs inside Javascript strings.

I've committed a tightened regex to CVS HEAD; similar pathological
input should no longer take hours/days/years(!) to scan.

- Gordon @ IA

joehung302 wrote:
>>If it was busy in regex extraction, rather than a network fetch,
>>there's probably a reproduceable problem with our regex expressions,
>>where they perform inefficiently against challenging input.
>>
>>Did you make note of the URI(s) affected, or can you find them again?
>>Feel free to send them to me directly if you'd like.
>>
>>We'd like to tighten our extraction regexes to avoid any such 
> 
> problems,
> 
>>as we've had to do a number of times in the past. In addition to
>>holding the thread, these kinds of problems also tend to monopolize 
> 
> the
> 
>>CPU, noticeably slowing the whole crawler.
> 
>
